text: although everyone thanks for spending
some of your lunch hour with us today
what I'm going to spend some time on is
discussing some recent security research
that we published and this is research
that was based on analysis of 455 days
worth of security event data from our
4,186 customers you can see that the
research is based on over a quarter
million verified security incidents that
our security operations center staff
were able to confirm from over seven
million events and more than a billion
security anomalies that were analyzed
over this particular time period and
there are five key findings from this
research that that I'm going to focus
this short talk on the first is that
we're seeing is that the initial phases
of the cyber kill chain are being
compressed and that makes your response
to security events need to adapt to
change to the attackers behavior the
second is that it used to be that
certain industries and certain sizes of
companies had a less of a risk of being
attacked and potentially getting
breached and we're seeing that that is
going away and I'll show you some data
around that the third is we're seeing an
increase in the use of automation the
fourth we'll talk a little about crypto
mining and crypto jacking and how we're
seeing that is really on the rise and
then fifth an oldie but a goodie a
persistent attack is on your web
applications and we'll talk a little bit
about that as well so first let's talk
about the cyber kill chain for those of
you that aren't familiar with the cyber
kill chain it was something it was
developed by Lockheed Martin you can go
and Google and learn more about it this
is a summary level view of the
traditional steps in the cyber kill
chain that attackers follow and it used
to be with attackers following this kind
of an approach where they initially do
reconnaissance then they look to
weaponize their attack they deliver that
particular attack and then exploit a
known vulnerability and install malware
on the on the host device and then
able to then gain control over that
particular device it used to be that
with this traditional kill chain you
could take preventative measures and
response measures at each one of these
steps and what we're seeing now is that
increasingly those first five steps of
the cyber kill chain are being
compressed through the use of automation
and we'll talk a little bit more about
that coming up in a moment what that
means is that the traditional approach
of trying to detect someone who's doing
reconnaissance in your environment and
then deny them access to your
environment needs to shift to more of a
disruption degradation deception or
contain strategy because of this
compressing of these initial stages of
the kill chain what this also means is
that you need to be able to respond much
faster when there is an activity of
security activity going on in your in
your network in your environment then
you used to with the previous kill chain
the second key insight from our research
really highlights the fact that it
doesn't matter or your industry any
longer and it doesn't matter your
company size attackers are really going
after anyone with an IP address now it
used to be that you know maybe if you
are in a nonprofit organization or in a
you know small company that you might
not think that you were at much risk but
the reality is that it doesn't matter
your industry and it doesn't matter your
company size you are at risk now and you
need to make sure that you've got the
right capabilities in order to be able
to identify attackers and to be able to
stop those attackers looking at it based
on a little bit more detail on specific
industries what this particular chart is
showing is the frequency of the
different types of attacks by industry
and there's one thing that jumps out
immediately I'm sure all of you the
bright orange is the web application
attacks regardless of industry that is
the the primary attack vector that we
see but you can see that the second and
third attack vectors do sometimes differ
based on industries so sometimes we see
denial of service attacks more in a
particular industry or brute force
attacks
other industry but application attacks
particularly web application attacks are
really the primary attack vector that is
regardless of the industry so as I
mentioned with the use of automation
what we're seeing is you can think of
this almost like robocalling
you know we all get those phone calls
you know they're gonna do surveys and
things like that or around the election
season think of this like Robo calling
or what the attackers are doing now is
they're using automation tools and
they're rolling through IP address
ranges so they'll take an IP address
range and they'll run automation at it
that includes the reconnaissance the
weaponization and the delivery and the
exploitation all in one single step
through automation and then they'll roll
to another IP address range and what's
interesting is that we found in our
research that it didn't really matter
we had a hypothesis that we might see
more frequency of this in public cloud
environments and the reality is is it
didn't actually show up statistically in
the data when we did the analysis that
regardless of whether you are you know
running in AWS public cloud or another
public cloud or you're running on Fram
or a combination and a hybrid
environment this technique of automation
is really going after IP addresses
regardless of where those environments
are actually located the next thing this
was a bit surprising to us we saw it
initially over this past summer with an
attack against a known vulnerability and
Oracle's WebLogic application server and
we've seen an increase starting around
that time period and and through the
through the fall where what attackers
are doing now is they're trying to place
crypto miners onto servers because they
believe that this is something a bit
more like a white-collar crime right
we're not stealing your customer
sensitive data we're not stealing Social
Security numbers we're not stealing
credit card information those sorts of
things all we're doing is we're stealing
compute resources in order to be able to
do crypto mining and be able to take the
profits from that crypto mining and be
able to put it into
our our wallet and so we're seeing an
increase in this type of attack because
of this perception that this is somehow
you know less risky but let's or less or
less less about a crime if you will but
let's be honest right this is this is
stealing this is still theft and and the
and those that are that are doing this
sort of thing should be prosecuted to
the fullest extent of the law but
there's this perception among many in
the in the in the in the hacking
community on the bad side that this is
somehow less of a crime than stealing
data and so that's why we believe we're
seeing the increase in this particular
type of attack and in particular the
Oracle WebLogic attack that I mentioned
that took place over the summer we saw
eighty-eight percent of those particular
attacks were specifically crypto jackin
attacks so this is something that
definitely you need to be aware of the
other thing that I would mention is from
some of you who've been in the industry
for you know maybe twenty thirty years
you might remember back to the early
days of websites and there was sometimes
some people in the IT departments that
said well there's a bunch of unused
capacity here on these servers so I'm
just gonna host a couple of websites for
myself and maybe some friends and things
like that one thing you need to be aware
of here is that same type of behavior is
going on as well with crypto miners so
what may look like an attack from the
outside actually could be your own staff
that's placing crypto miners so don't
just look at this as an external issue
but look at this as both a potential
internal issue as well as an external
issue so as I mentioned application
attacks and you saw the data by industry
application attacks really are the the
vast majority of the initial attack
vectors that we see and sometimes these
will be used in combination with one
another as well so you'll see a web
application attack that's also you know
combined with a brute force attack for
example or a reconnaissance effort but
what this data is showing from left to
right is based on the months of the of
the analysis that we did the frequency
of the various different types of
attacks and you can see
that web application attacks just
continue month over month over month to
be the primary attack vector so what can
you do about it I want to give you some
some practical guidance here so I'm
gonna give you kind of a top 10 list of
10 things that you can do to help
prepare your organization better for
2019 the first is knowing what you have
being able to have a solid understanding
of what compute resources you have where
they're running having asset inventories
having topology maps and relationships
and dependency Maps is a critical
foundational component to protecting
yourself many organizations have systems
that are not well documented
particularly if those are systems that
are you know supporting development and
test environments but if those
environments are accessible to the
Internet and many of them are you really
need to be thinking about protection
across your entire landscape not just on
your production systems but your
development and test systems as well the
second is it really comes down to what's
your appetite for risk right and we we
can't necessarily cover everything at
all the way you know we have limited
resources we have limited budgets and so
having a proper risk analysis and
understanding what your risk tolerances
are and what systems do you need to have
at a high level of protection versus
what systems maybe you just need to have
at a basic vulnerability scanning level
of protection for example you might say
that for your production systems I need
to have a 24 by 7 security operation
senator center that's monitoring events
and verifying incidents there for your
web applications or for systems that are
running critical data that might have
customer data in it or a credit card
data in it you might want to have an
even higher level of protection but then
for you know your development test
systems you might want to have more of
that foundational level where you're
just having vulnerability scanning and
risk analysis type of capability so that
would be the the second thing that I
would say is thinking about different
risk tolerances and different coverage
levels to be able to meet your resource
and your budget constraints the third is
if you don't already have an incident
response plan start writing one on the
plane
right at home because you don't want to
wait until you've been breached to
figure out okay what do we do now
now before you've been breached is the
time to really define an incident
response plan
the fourth is good practice of creating
a culture of security within the
organization
many of you probably are on DevOps teams
or you know work with DevOps or parts of
your organizations there's a extension
of the DevOps term referred to as Deb
sack ops so this is one way in which you
can create a culture of security in your
organization is to get everyone thinking
about security all the way back into you
know development security isn't
something that you should only be
thinking about when you're about to put
an application into production but you
should be thinking about security from
the first line of code that you've
written the fifth is you've got to
leverage automation as I mentioned
earlier based on our research findings
the hackers are using automation more
and more and you need to make sure that
that is a tool in your arsenal in order
to be able to protect yourself so the
ability to automate log collection to be
able to use machine learning to be able
to support log analysis those would be
good examples of automation so moving to
the second half of the the top ten
practical steps here the sixth one is
using the principle of least privilege
for your access don't over assign
privileges one of the most popular ways
that hackers are able to exploit your
systems is by gaining access to user IDs
and if you are over assigning privileges
that is increasing the risk for your
organization so really think about the
least privilege level what is the
minimum level of capability and
permissions that I need to give to this
particular user or classes of user
rather than you know giving people you
know higher levels of access that might
not necessarily need it the seventh one
and this is a challenge because there
are a tremendous number of
vulnerabilities and in you know
commercial applications open source etc
actively managing vulnerabilities in
your environment knowing what
vulnerabilities do you have are those
vulnerabilities actually in your images
that you're using to be able to deploy

know vulnerabilities that are in you
know previously existing deployed
systems and then having a risk analysis
of those vulnerabilities understanding
if that vulnerability gets exploited
what is the risk so using the example of
web logic that I mentioned earlier you
know a vulnerability to a critical
application server component could
potentially allow access to multiple
levels up and down the application stack
so that's something you're gonna want to
prioritize you know much higher in terms
of patching that type of a vulnerability
but then also understanding what
vulnerabilities are actually actively
being exploited so again the WebLogic
example I've used a few times now is a
really good example our researchers knew
about this vulnerability for a year
before we saw it actively being
exploited so you have to triage you have
to understand you know what your
resources can actually handle and you
might choose to not patch certain
vulnerabilities because there aren't any
active exploits that are occurring
against that particular vulnerability
and focusing your time more on the
vulnerabilities to have a history like
Apache struts for example of active
exploits and ongoing exploits the eighth
one is really honing in on compliance
and and making sure that you have good
compliance policies and a good
understanding of what level of security
controls you need to have in place based
on mandates that you might have to
adhere to in your particular industry or
internal policy so compliance is
actually a critical foundation to having
a healthy security program and being
able to understand your risk posture and
your risk tolerance number nine you want
to be able to be actively monitoring so
you want to be able to make sure that
this is a 24 by 7 activity it's not
something that you're gonna monitor on a
periodic basis but you have to make this
part of your daily operations and the
number 10 kind of a big catch-all here
is really need to think about your

think about the
custom applications that you write as

are and what your risk postures are so
